messages.content: Do photons age, or are they immutable?

Photons are particles of light that are created or absorbed in various processes, but they do not "age" in the same sense that other objects do. Photons are not subject to the physical effects of aging, such as the wear and tear of atoms and molecules in other objects.

However, photons can be absorbed and re-emitted by other objects, and their properties can be altered in the process. For example, photons can be absorbed by atoms or molecules and cause them to become excited, which can eventually result in the emission of a new photon with a different energy. In this sense, photons can be "rejuvenated" or "replenished" through these interactions, but they do not "age" in the same sense that other objects do.

So while photons do not "age" in the same way as other objects, they can still be affected by the interactions with other objects and can change in their properties as a result.
What is redshift then, in relation to photons?

Redshift is a phenomenon in which an object's spectral lines shift towards the red end of the visible spectrum (or the opposite, towards the blue end of the spectrum) when viewed from a different position or in a different frame of reference. This phenomenon is usually observed in the spectra of distant objects, such as stars and galaxies, and is often interpreted as the result of the Doppler effect, in which the frequency of a wave is increased by the motion of the observer relative to the source of the wave.

In the case of photons, redshift can occur due to the fact that photons are particles and are therefore affected by the motion of the observer relative to the source of the photons. When an observer is moving relative to the source of the photons, the frequency of the photons can appear to be higher or lower than it would be if the observer were stationary relative to the source. This is because the photons are "doppler shifted" by the motion of the observer, and the frequency of the photons appears to be different to the observer depending on their relative motion.

So, in short, redshift is a real phenomenon that occurs when an object's spectral lines shift towards the red end of the visible spectrum (or the opposite) when viewed from a different position or in a different frame of reference, and this can be caused by the motion of the observer relative to the source of the waves or photons.
